list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Prove that the sum of three consecutive positive integers is divisible
by $3$.
list.markScheme:
Let $n, \, n + 1$ and $n+2$ be three consecutive positive integers for
some $n \in \mathbb{Z^{+}}$.
The sum of the three integers is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{8em} n + (n + 1) + (n+2) &= 3n + 3 \\[6pt]
&= 3(n+1) \hspace{3em} [\text{multiple of $3$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the sum of three consecutive positive integers is divisible by
$3$.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Consider two consecutive positive integers, $k$ and $k+1$.
Show that the difference of their squares is equal to the sum of the two
integers.
list.markScheme:
The difference of the squares of $k$ and $k+1$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{9.5em}(k+1)^2 - k^2 &= k^2 + 2k + 1 - k^2 \\[6pt]
&= 2k + 1 \\[6pt]
&= k + (k + 1) \hspace{3em} [\text{sum of $k$ and $k+1$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the difference of the squares of two consecutive positive integers
is equal to their sum.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
The product of three consecutive integers is increased by the middle
integer.
Prove that the result is a perfect cube.
list.markScheme:
Let $n-1,\, n$ and $n+1$ be three consecutive integers for some
$n \in \mathbb{Z}$.
The product of these three integers is

$$
\begin{aligned}
(n-1) \times n \times (n + 1) &=  n \times (n^2 - 1) \\[6pt]
&= n^3 - n\end{aligned}
$$

If this product is
increased by the middle integer, $n$, then the result would be

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{6.25em} (n^3 - n) + n &= n^3 \hspace{3em} [\text{perfect cube}]\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the result of increasing the product of three consecutive integers
by the middle integer is a perfect cube.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Using mathematical induction, prove that
$1^2 + 2^2 + \cdots + n^2 = \dfrac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}$ for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.
list.markScheme:
Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{8.3em} 1^2 + 2^2 + \cdots + n^2 = \dfrac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6} \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.
Base case. For $n = 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{(1)(1+1)(2(1)+1)}{6} &= \dfrac{(1)(2)(3)}{6} \hspace{4.4em} \\[6pt]
&= 1 \\[9pt]
&= 1^2\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
1^2 + 2^2 + \cdots + k^2 = \dfrac{k(k+1)(2k+1)}{6} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
1^2 + 2^2 + \cdots + k^2 + (k+1)^2 = \dfrac{(k+1)(k+2)(2k+3)}{6} \hspace{2.2em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3em} 1^2 + 2^2 + \cdots + k^2 + (k+1)^2 &= \big[1^2 + 2^2 + \cdots + k^2\big] + (k+1)^2 \\[11pt]
&= \dfrac{k(k+1)(2k+1)}{6} + (k+1)^2 \hspace{3em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[7pt]
&= \dfrac{k(k+1)(2k+1) + 6(k+1)^2}{6} \\[6pt]
&= \dfrac{(k+1)\big[k(2k+1) + 6(k+1)\big]}{6} \\[5pt]
&= \dfrac{(k+1)\big[2k^2 + 7k + 6\big]}{6} \\[7pt]
&= \dfrac{(k+1)(k+2)(2k+3)}{6}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as
well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

list.title: Question 7
list.markScheme:
Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.3em} 1\cdot2^1 + 2\cdot2^2 + 3\cdot2^3 + \cdots + n\cdot2^n =  2 + (n-1)2^{n+1} \hspace{2em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.
Base case. For $n = 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
1\cdot2^1 &= 2 \\[6pt]
&= 2 + (1-1)2^{1+1}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
1\cdot2^1 + 2\cdot2^2 + 3\cdot2^3 + \cdots + k\cdot2^k &=  2 + (k-1)2^{k+1} \hspace{1.8em} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
1\cdot2^1 + 2\cdot2^2 + 3\cdot2^3 + \cdots + k\cdot2^k + (k+1)2^{k+1} &=  2 + k\cdot2^{k+2} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\hspace{1.25em}1\cdot2^1 + 2\cdot2^2 + 3\cdot2^3 + \cdots + k\cdot2^k + (k+1)2^{k+1} = \\[6pt]
&= \big[1\cdot2^1 + 2\cdot2^2 + 3\cdot2^3 + \cdots + k\cdot2^k\big] + (k+1)2^{k+1} \\[6pt]
&= \big[2 + (k-1)2^{k+1}\big] +(k+1)2^{k+1} \hspace{3em} [\text{by (IH)}]  \\[6pt]
&= 2 + (k-\cancel{1} + k+\cancel{1})2^{k+1} \\[6pt]
&= 2 + (2k)2^{k+1} \\[6pt]
&= 2 + k\cdot2^{k+2}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Using the method of proof by contradiction, prove that $\sqrt{3}$ is
irrational.
list.markScheme:
Let's assume that it is not true that $\sqrt{3}$ is irrational. Then
$\sqrt{3}$
is rational, so there are positive integers $a$ and $b$ ($b\neq 0$) such
that

$$
\sqrt{3}=\dfrac{a}{b}

$$

we can also assume that this fraction has
been written in lowest terms, so $a$ and $b$ have no common factors.
Squaring both sides,

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\sqrt{3})^2 &= \left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^2 \rule[-4mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
3 &= \dfrac{a^2}{b^2} \rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
a^2 &= 3b^2 \qref{(1)}\rule[-2mm]{0pt}{8mm}\end{aligned}
$$

From (1) we
deduce that $a^2$ is divisible by $3$ and therefore $a$ is divisible by
$3$. Then we can write $a=3p$ for some positive integer $p$.
Substituting $a=3p$ in (1), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
(3p)^2 &= 3b^2 \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{5mm}\\
9p^2 &= 3b^2 \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
3p^2&= b^2 \rule[-2mm]{0pt}{6.5mm}\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore $b$ is
also divisible by $3$. This is a contradiction, as $a$ and $b$ have no
common factors.
Thus our original assumption is false, and by the method of proof by
contradiction, we conclude $\sqrt{3}$ is irrational.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Let $r \in \mathbb{R}, r\neq 1$. Use the method of mathematical
induction to prove that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{8.3em} 1+r+r^2+\cdots+r^n=\frac{1-r^{n+1}}{1-r} \hspace{2em} \text{for all } n\in \mathbb{Z}^+. \\
\end{aligned}
$$
list.markScheme:
Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{7.2em} 1+r+r^2+\cdots+r^n=\frac{1-r^{n+1}}{1-r} \hspace{2em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.
Base case. For $n = 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1-r^{1+1}}{1-r}  &= \frac{1-r^2}{1-r} \\[6pt]
&= \frac{(1+r)\bcancel{(1-r)}}{\bcancel{1-r}} \\[13pt]
&= 1+ r\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
1+r+r^2+\ldots+r^k=\frac{1-r^{k+1}}{1-r} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for
some $k \geq 1$.
Inductive step: To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
1+r+r^2+\ldots + r^k +r^{k+1} = \frac{1-r^{(k+1)+1}}{1-r} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
1+r+r^2+\ldots + r^k +r^{k+1} &= (1+r+r^2+\ldots + r^k) + r^{k+1} \\[11pt]
&= \frac{1-r^{k+1}}{1-r} + r^{k+1} \hspace{3em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[6pt]
&= \frac{1-r^{k+1}}{1-r} + \frac{r^{k+1}(1-r)}{1-r} \\[5pt]
&= \frac{1-\cancel{r^{k+1}} + \cancel{r^{k+1}} - r^{k+2}}{1-r}\\[6pt]
&= \frac{1 - r^{(k+1)+1}}{1-r}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as
well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

list.title: Question 10
list.content: Prove by contradiction that the equation $3x^3-7x^2+5=0$ has no integer roots.
list.markScheme:
Assume that the equation $3x^3-7x^2+5=0$ has at least one integer root, $n$.
Therefore, $n$ satisfies the equation

$$
\begin{align*}
    3n^3-7n^2+5 &= 0 \\[10pt]
    3n^3+5 &= 7n^2 \\[-12pt]
\end{align*}
$$

Consider first the case where $n$ is odd. $3n^3$ is odd and hence $3n^3 + 5$ is even. $7n^2$ is odd, therefore

$$
\begin{align*}
    3n^3+5 &\neq 7n^2 \\[-12pt]
\end{align*}
$$

Now consider the case where $n$ is even. $3n^3$ is even and hence $3n^3 + 5$ is odd. $7n^2$ is even, therefore

$$
\begin{align*}
    3n^3+5 &\neq 7n^2 \\[-12pt]
\end{align*}
$$

We have shown that for $n \in \mathbb{Z}$, whether $n$ is odd or even, the equation is not satisfied. Hence there is a contradiction.
Thus our original assumption is false, and by the method of proof by contradiction, we conclude that $3x^3-7x^2+5=0$ has no integer roots.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
The Fibonacci sequence is defined as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_0 &= 0,\hspace{0.25em} a_1 = 1,\hspace{0.25em} a_2 = 1, \\[6pt]
a_n &= a_{n-1}+a_{n-2} \hspace{0.5em}\text{for}\hspace{0.5em} n \geq 2. \qref{(FS)}\end{aligned}
$$

Prove by mathematical induction that
$a_1^2+a_2^2+\cdots+a_n^2=a_na_{n+1}$, where $n\in\mathbb{Z}^+$.
list.markScheme:
Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{8.3em} a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_n^2=a_na_{n+1} \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.
Base case. For $n = 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_1^2 &= 1^2 \\[6pt]
&= 1\cdot 1 \\[6pt]
&= a_1a_2\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_k^2 = a_ka_{k+1} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some
$k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_k^2 + a_{k+1}^2= a_{k+1}a_{k+2} \hspace{2.2em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_k^2 + a_{k+1}^2 &= \big(a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_k^2\big) + a_{k+1}^2 \\[6pt]
&= a_ka_{k+1} + a_{k+1}^2 \hspace{3em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[7pt]
&= \big(a_k + a_{k+1}\big)a_{k+1} \\[7pt]
&= a_{k+2}a_{k+1} \hspace{3em} [\text{by (FS)}] \\[7pt]
&= a_{k+1}a_{k+2}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Let $y = x^2 e^x$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Find $\dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}$. [1]

- Prove by mathematical induction that

  $$
  \hspace{4em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^n}{\mathrm{d}x^n}\big(x^2e^x\big) = \big(n(n-1) + 2nx + x^2\big)e^x \hspace{1.5em} \text{for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, $n\geq2$.} 
  $$

  [7]
list.markScheme:
- Using the product rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big(x^2 e^x\big) \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= 2xe^x + x^2e^x} \hspace{1.95em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.65em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^n}{\mathrm{d}x^n}\big(x^2e^x\big) = \big(n(n-1) + 2nx + x^2\big)e^x \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n\geq2$}] \end{aligned}
  $$

  Using induction, we will prove that P$(n)$
$\text{holds for all \(n \in \mathbb{Z}^+\), \(n\geq2\).}$
  Base case. For $n = 2$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.4em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^2}{\mathrm{d}x^2}\big(x^2e^x\big) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \left[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big(x^2e^x\big)\right] \\[3pt]
  &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \big(2xe^x + x^2e^x\big) \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[10pt]
  &= 2e^x + 2xe^x + 2xe^x + x^2e^x\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.4em} &= \big(2 + 4x + x^2\big)e^x \\[13pt]
  &= \big(2(2-1) + 2(2)x + x^2\big)e^x\end{aligned}
  $$


Hence P$(2)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 2$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\mathrm{d}^k}{\mathrm{d}x^k}\big(x^2e^x\big) = \big(k(k-1) + 2kx + x^2\big)e^x \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 2$.
Inductive Step: To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.5em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}}\big(x^2e^x\big) = \big((k+1)k + 2(k+1)x + x^2\big)e^x \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}}\big(x^2e^x\big) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \left[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}^k}{\mathrm{d}x^k}\big(x^2e^x\big)\right] \\[3pt]
&= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \left[\big(k(k-1) + 2kx + x^2\big)e^x \right] \hspace{3em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[11pt]
&= \big(2k + 2x\big)e^x + \big(k(k-1) + 2kx + x^2\big)e^x \\[14pt]
&= \big((k+1)k + 2(k+1)x + x^2\big)e^x.\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$
holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(2)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 2$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that
P$(n)$ holds for all $\text{\(n\hspace{-0.2em}\in\hspace{-0.2em}\mathbb{Z}^+\hspace{-0.2em},\hspace{0.05em}n\hspace{-0.2em}\geq\hspace{-0.2em}2\)}$.

list.content: Use mathematical induction to prove that $n^3-9n^2+26n-24$ is divisible by $6$ for all $n\geq 5$.

Let $P(n)$ be the proposition that $n^3-9n^2+26n-24$ is divisible by $6$.
The first step is to verify the base case ($n=5$).

$$

    P(5)&=(5)^3-9(5)^2+26(5)-24\\
    &=6
\end{align*}
$$

$P(5)$ is divisible by $6$ therefore it is true.

$$
    \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
$$

Assume $P(k)$ is true.

    P(k)&=k^3-9k^2+26k-24\\

Where $k, A\in \mathbb{Z^+}$ and $k\geq5$.
Now we will consider the $(k+1)^{\text{th}}$ case and by using the assumption we will show that $P(k+1)$ is divisible by $6$.

$P(k+1)$ is divisible by $6$.

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} f'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big[(x+1)e^{-2x}\big] \\[6pt]
  &= e^{-2x} - 2(x+1)e^{-2x} \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= \big[1 - 2(x+1)\big]e^{-2x}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $\mathrm{P}(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.9em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^nf}{\mathrm{d}x^n} = \big[n(-2)^{n-1} + (-2)^n(x+1)\big]e^{-2x} \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that $\mathrm{P}(n)$
holds for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

Base case. For $n = 1$, from part (a), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}x} = \big[1 - 2(x+1)\big]e^{-2x}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that $\mathrm{P}(k)$ holds
for some $k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\mathrm{d}^kf}{\mathrm{d}x^k} = \big[k(-2)^{k-1} + (-2)^k(x+1)\big]e^{-2x} \hspace{0.5em} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that $\mathrm{P}(k+1)$ holds, we
need to show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.6em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}f}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}} = \big[(k+1)(-2)^k + (-2)^{(k+1)}(x+1)\big]e^{-2x}\end{aligned}
$$

If we differentiate both sides of the equation (IH), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.55em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}f}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}} &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\Big[\big[k(-2)^{k-1} + (-2)^k(x+1)\big]e^{-2x}\Big] \\[14pt]
&= \big[(-2)^k\big]e^{-2x} - 2\big[k(-2)^{k-1} + (-2)^k(x+1)\big]e^{-2x} \\[16pt]
&= \big[(-2)^k\big]e^{-2x} + \big[k(-2)^k + (-2)^{k+1}(x+1)\big]e^{-2x} \\[16pt]
&= \big[(k+1)(-2)^k + (-2)^{(k+1)}(x+1)\big]e^{-2x} \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $P(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
Using the principle of mathematical induction, prove that $n(n^2+5)$ is
divisible by $6$ for all integers $n \geq 1$.
list.markScheme:
Notation: For $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}$, $m \mid n$ means $m$ divides $n$ or
$n$ is divisible by $m$.
Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.1em} 6 \mid n(n^2+5) \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n \geq 1$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.
Base case. For $n = 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
6 \mid (1)(1^2+5) = 6 \end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
6 \mid k(k^2+5) \hspace{2.5em} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some
$k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.55em} 6 \mid (k+1)\big[(k+1)^2+5\big] \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

If we rewrite the expression on the right hand side of the statement
$(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
(k+1)\big[(k+1)^2+5\big] &= (k+1)\big[(k^2+5)+(2k+1)\big] \\[6pt]
&= k(k^2+5) + (k^2+5) + (k+1)(2k+1) \\[6pt]
&= k(k^2+5) + (3k^2 + 3k + 6) \\[6pt]
&= k(k^2+5) + 3\big[k(k+1) + 2\big] \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
$$

Since either $k$ or $k+1$ is even, $k(k+1)$ is divisible by $2$.
Hence we deduce

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{6em} 2 &\mid k(k+1) + 2 \\[6pt]
6 &\mid 3\big[k(k+1) + 2\big] \\[6pt]
6 &\mid k(k^2+5) + 3\big[k(k+1) + 2\big] \hspace{3em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[6pt]
6 &\mid (k+1)\big[(k+1)^2+5\big] \hspace{3em} [\text{by $(2)$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

list.content:
- Solve the inequality $x^2 \geq 2x + 3$. [2]

- Use mathematical induction to prove that $2^n > n^2 - 2$ for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, $n \geq 3$.[6]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the graphs of $y = x^2$ and $y = 2x + 3$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2657c2a5-86af-44db-8be4-bfd4d027e790/images/2ce2fde1-d607-4fa0-9109-01ca871a4538/8559be520206e999f46f83d313584ee1a94282b7.svg)


  Using the $x$-coordinates of A and B, we see that the graph of
$y = x^2$ is above the graph of $y = 2x+3$ when $x < -1$ and
$x > 3$, and the graphs intersect at $x = -1,3$.
  Hence the solution set to the inequality $x^2 \geq 2x+3$ is
$\answer{(-\infty,-1] \cup [3, \infty)}$
- Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.2em} 2^n &> n^2 - 2 \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n\geq3$}] \hspace{1.9em}\end{aligned}
  $$


Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, $n \geq 3$.
Base case. For $n = 3$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
2^3 = 8 &> 3^2 - 2 = 7\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(3)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 3$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
2^k &> k^2 - 2 \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 3$.
Inductive step: To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.5em} 2^{k+1} &> (k+1)^2 - 2 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the
left hand side of the inequality $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{6.8em} 2^{k+1} &= 2\cdot2^k \\[6pt]
&>2\hspace{0.05em}[k^2 - 2] \hspace{3em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[6pt]
&= k^2 + [k^2 - 4] \\[6pt]
[\text{by part (a)}] \hspace{3em} &\geq 2k+3 + [k^2 - 4] \\[6pt]
&= [k^2 + 2k + 1] - 2 \\[6pt]
&= (k+1)^2 - 2 \end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(3)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 3$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that
P$(n)$ holds for all $\text{\(n\hspace{-0.2em}\in\hspace{-0.2em}\mathbb{Z}^+\hspace{-0.2em},\hspace{0.05em}n\hspace{-0.2em}\geq\hspace{-0.2em}3\)}$.

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
- Show that
$\dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{n+1}} < \sqrt{n+1} - \sqrt{n}$,
where $n \in \mathbb{Z},\hspace{0.1em} n\geq 0$. [3]

- Hence show that $\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} < 2\sqrt{2} - 2$.
[2]

- Prove by mathematical induction that

  $$
  \hspace{4em} \sum_{r = 2}^n \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} < 2\sqrt{n} - 2 \hspace{2em} \text{for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, $n \geq 2$.}
  
  $$

  [9]
list.markScheme:
- For any $n \in \mathbb{Z},\hspace{0.1em} n \geq 0$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \sqrt{n+1} - \sqrt{n} &= \left[\dfrac{\sqrt{n+1} - \sqrt{n}}{1}\right] \left[\dfrac{\sqrt{n+1} + \sqrt{n}}{\sqrt{n+1} + \sqrt{n}}\right] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{(\cancel{n}+1) - \cancel{n}}{\sqrt{n+1} + \sqrt{n}} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{n+1} + \sqrt{n}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.8em} \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{n+1}} < \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{n+1} + \sqrt{n}} \hspace{2em} \big[\text{since $\sqrt{n+1} > \sqrt{n}$}\hspace{0.1em}\big]\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{\dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{n+1}} < \sqrt{n+1} - \sqrt{n}} \hspace{3.8em} \qref{(1)}
  $$

- Hence, substituting $n = 1$ in the inequality $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{2}} &< \sqrt{2} - 1 \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} < 2\sqrt{2} - 2}
  $$

- Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6em} \sum_{r = 2}^n \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} < 2\sqrt{n} - 2 \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n\geq2$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using math induction, we will prove that P$(n)$
$\text{holds for all \(n \in \mathbb{Z}^+\), \(n\geq2\).}$
  Base case. For $n = 2$, from part (b), we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} < 2\sqrt{2} - 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence P$(2)$
holds.
  Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for
some $k \geq 2$. In other words, we assume that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r = 2}^k \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} < 2\sqrt{k} - 2 \hspace{1.5em} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  for some $k \geq 2$.
  Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need
to show that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} \sum_{r = 2}^{k+1} \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} < 2\sqrt{k+1} - 2 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$


From the left hand side of the inequality $(2)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{8em} \sum_{r = 2}^{k+1} \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} &= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{k+1}} + \sum_{r = 2}^k \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} \\[6pt]
&< \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{k+1}} + \big(2\sqrt{k} - 2\big) \hspace{2em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[12pt]
&< \big(2\sqrt{k+1} - \cancel{2\sqrt{k}}\big) + \big(\cancel{2\sqrt{k}} - 2\big) \hspace{2em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[18pt]
&= 2\sqrt{k+1} -2\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(2)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 2$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that
P$(n)$ holds for all $\text{\(n\hspace{-0.2em}\in\hspace{-0.2em}\mathbb{Z}^+\hspace{-0.2em},\hspace{0.05em}n\hspace{-0.2em}\geq\hspace{-0.2em}2\)}$.

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
This question asks you to explore the sequence defined by

$$
u_n=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}(\alpha^n-\beta^n)
$$

where $\alpha$ and $\beta$
are the roots of the quadratic equation $x^2-4x+1=0, \, \alpha > \beta$
and $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

- Find the value of $\alpha$ and the value of $\beta$. Give your answers in the form $a \pm \sqrt{b}$, where $a,b \in \mathbb{Z^+}$.[3]

- Hence find the values of $u_1$ and $u_2$. [4]

- Show that $\alpha^2 = 4\alpha -1$ and $\beta^2 = 4\beta - 1$. [1]

- Hence show that $u_{n+2} = 4u_{n+1}-u_n$.[4]

- Suppose that $u_n$ and $u_{n+1}$ are integers. Show that $u_{n+2}$ is also an integer.[2]

- Hence show that $u_n$ is an integer for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.[2]


Now consider the sequence defined by

$$
v_n = \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^n + \beta^n\right).
$$


- Find the exact values of $v_1$ and $v_2$.[4]

- Express $v_{n+2}$ in terms of $v_{n+1}$ and $v_n$.[4]

- Hence show that $v_n$ is a multiple of $\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$ for all $n \in \mathbb{Z^+}$.[4]
list.markScheme:
- Completing the square for $x^2-4x+1=0$ we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  (x-2)^2-3&=0 \\[8pt]
  (x-2)^2 &= 3 \\[8pt]
  x - 2 &= \pm\sqrt{3} \\[8pt]
  x &= 2 \pm\sqrt{3}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Given that $\alpha > \beta$, we have $\answer{\alpha = 2 + \sqrt{3} \text{ and } \beta = 2 - \sqrt{3}}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_1 &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha - \beta\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(2 + \sqrt{3} - \left(2 - \sqrt{3}\right)\right) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-1.3em}\tcbhighmath{u_1 = 1} \hspace{3em}\text{[By using G.D.C.]}\\[8pt]
  u_2 &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^2 - \beta^2\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\left(2 + \sqrt{3}\right)^2 - \left(2 - \sqrt{3}\right)^2\right) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-1.3em}\tcbhighmath{u_2 = 4} \hspace{3em}\text{[By using G.D.C.]}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Given that $\alpha$ is a root of the quadratic equation, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \alpha^2 - 4\alpha + 1 &= 0 \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-1.3em}\tcbhighmath{\alpha^2 = 4\alpha -1}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Similarly

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \beta^2 - 4\beta + 1 &= 0 \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-1.3em}\tcbhighmath{\beta^2 = 4\beta -1}\\[-1cm]
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Using the expressions from part (c), we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_{n+2} &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n+2}-\beta^{n+2}\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n}\alpha^2-\beta^{n}\beta^2\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n}(4\alpha - 1)-\beta^{n}(4\beta - 1)\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(4\alpha^{n+1}-\alpha^n - 4\beta^{n+1}+\beta^n\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(4\left(\alpha^{n+1}-\beta^{n+1}\right)-\left(\alpha^n-\beta^n\right)\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{4\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n+1}-\beta^{n+1}\right)-\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}(\alpha^n - \beta^n) \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-2.25em}\tcbhighmath{u_{n+2} = 4u_{n+1}-u_n}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Using the results from part (d), we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_n \text{ and } u_{n+1} &\text{ are integers} \\[12pt]
  -u_n \text{ and } 4u_{n+1} &\text{ are integers} \\[12pt] 
  4u_{n+1}-u_n &\text{ is an integer} \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-0.845cm}\tcbhighmath{u_{n+2} \text{ is an integer}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Using part (e), we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_1 &= 1 \text{ is an integer (by part (b))} \\[12pt]
  u_2 &= 4 \text{ is an integer (by part (b))}\\[12pt] 
  u_3 & \text{ is an integer (by part (e))} \\
  & \enskip \vdots & \\[3pt]
  u_n & \text{ is an integer (by part (e))} \\[-9pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Hence,$\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{we conclude that $u_n$ is an integer for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}.}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  v_1 &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha + \beta\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(2 + \sqrt{3} + 2 - \sqrt{3}\right) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-1em}\tcbhighmath{v_1 = \dfrac{2\sqrt{3}}{3}} \\[8pt]
  v_2 &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^2 + \beta^2\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\left(2 + \sqrt{3}\right)^2 + \left(2 - \sqrt{3}\right)^2\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(4 + 4\sqrt{3} + 3 + 4 -4\sqrt{3} + 3\right)\\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-1em}\tcbhighmath{v_2 = \dfrac{7\sqrt{3}}{3}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- By a procedure similar to part (d), we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  v_{n+2} &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n+2}+\beta^{n+2}\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n}\alpha^2+\beta^{n}\beta^2\right) \\[8pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  From part (c) we have $\alpha^2=4\alpha-1$ and $\beta^2=\beta-1$.

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  v_{n+2} &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n}(4\alpha - 1)+\beta^{n}(4\beta - 1)\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(4\alpha^{n+1}-\alpha^n + 4\beta^{n+1}-\beta^n\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(4\left(\alpha^{n+1}+\beta^{n+1}\right)-\left(\alpha^n+\beta^n\right)\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{4\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n+1}+\beta^{n+1}\right)-\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}(\alpha^n + \beta^n) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-2.05em}\tcbhighmath{v_{n+2}= 4v_{n+1}-v_n}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- First suppose that $v_n$ and $v_{n+1}$ are both multiples of $\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$. Let $v_n=\dfrac{p\sqrt{3}}{3}$ and $v_{n+1}=\dfrac{q\sqrt{3}}{3}$ where $p,q \in \mathbb{Z}$. Using the result from part (h), we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  v_{n+2} &= \dfrac{4q\sqrt{3}}{3} - \dfrac{p\sqrt{3}}{3} \\[8pt]
  &= (4q-p)\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  If $v_n$ and $v_{n+1}$ are both multiples of $\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$, then $v_{n+2}$ is also. From part (g) we notice that $v_1$ and $v_2$ are both multiples of $\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$.
  Therefore,$\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{$v_n$ is a multiple of $\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$ for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}}$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
This question asks you to investigate some properties of hexagonal
numbers.
Hexagonal numbers can be represented by dots as shown below where $h_n$
denotes the $n$th hexagonal number,
$n\in \mathbb{N}$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f04773c8-5027-4b36-ab13-ded60788d8d3/images/4d8392bc-6e52-4566-b47d-6f63c2090a5b/b2b46cf7a1e76fe3e94b0c5adbb806ad8bd4f38f.svg)


Note that $6$ points are required to create the regular hexagon $h_2$
with side of length $1$, while $15$ points are required to create the
next hexagon $h_3$ with side of length $2$, and so
on.

- Write down the value of $h_5$.[1]

- By examining the pattern, show that $h_{n+1} = h_{n}+4n+1$,
$n\in \mathbb{N}$. [3]

- By expressing $h_n$ as a series, show that $h_n =  2n^2-n$,
$n\in \mathbb{N}$.[3]

- Hence, determine whether $2016$ is a hexagonal number.[3]

- Find the least hexagonal number which is greater than
$80\hspace{0.10em}000$.[5]

- Consider the statement:
  $45$ is the only hexagonal number which is divisible by $9$.
  Show that this statement is false.[2]


Matt claims that given $h_1 = 1$ and $h_{n+1} = h_n + 4n + 1$,
$n \in \mathbb{N}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
h_n &= 2n^2 - n, \quad n\in\mathbb{N}.  \end{aligned}
$$


- Show, by mathematical induction, that Matt's claim is true
for all $n\in \mathbb{N}$.  [7]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{45}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h_2 &= h_1 + 5 \\[12pt]
  h_3 &= h_2 + 9 \\[12pt]
  h_4 &= h_3 + 13 \\[12pt]
  h_5 &= h_4 + 17
  \end{align*}
  $$

  And therefore

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h_{n+1} &= h_n + u_n
  \end{align*}    
  $$

  Where $u_n$ is the $n$th term of an arithmetic sequence with first term $u_1 = 5$ and common difference $d=4$.
  Using the formula for the $n$th term of an arithmetic sequence, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_n &= u_1 + (n-1)d \\[12pt]
  &= 5 + 4(n-1) \\[12pt]
  u_n &= 4n + 1
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Hence

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  & \hspace{-2.125em}\tcbhighmath{h_{n+1} = h_{n} + 4n + 1}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Using part (b), we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h_1 &= 1 \\[10pt]
  h_2 &= 1 + u_1\\[10pt]
  h_3 &= 1 + u_1 + u_2 \\[10pt]
  h_4 &= 1 + u_1 + u_2 + u_3 \\
  & \hspace{0.53em} \vdots \\
  h_{n} &= 1+ u_1 + \cdots + u_{n-1}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Hence, the general term can be obtained by using the formula for the sum of an arithmetic series

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h_n &= 1 + S_{n-1} \\[10pt]
  &= 1 + \dfrac{n-1}{2}\big[ u_1 + u_{n-1} \big]\\[10pt]
  &= 1 + \dfrac{n-1}{2}\big[ 5 + 5 + 4(n-2) \big]\\[10pt]
  &= 1 + \dfrac{n-1}{2}\big[ 4n + 2 \big] \\[10pt]
  &= 1 + \dfrac{n-1}{2}\big[ 2(2n + 1) \big] \\[10pt]
  &= 1 + (n-1)(2n+1) \\[10pt]
  &= 1 + 2n^2 - n - 1 \\[10pt]
  &\hspace{0.275em}\tcbhighmath{ = 2n^2-n }
  \end{align*}
  $$

- We attempt to solve $h_n = 2016$ for some $n \in \mathbb{N}$ as
follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_n &= 2016 \\[12pt]
  2n^2-n &= 2016 \\[12pt]
  2n^2-n-2016 &= 0 \\[12pt]
  n &= 32 \hspace{4.2em} [\hspace{0.1em}\text{by using G.D.C.}\hspace{0.1em}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore,$\answer{\text{\(2016\) is the \(32\)nd hexagonal number}}$
- We solve the inequality $h_n > 80\hspace{0.1em}000$ as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_n &> 80\hspace{0.1em}000 \\[12pt]
  2n^2-n &> 80\hspace{0.1em}000 \\[12pt]
  2n^2-n - 80\hspace{0.1em}000 &> 0 \\[12pt]
  n &> 200.25 \hspace{2.5em} [\hspace{0.1em}\text{by using G.D.C.}\hspace{0.1em}]\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore, the first hexagonal number greater than
$80\hspace{0.1em}000$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_{201} &= 2\left(201^2\right)-201 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 80\hspace{0.1em}601}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Observe that the general term of an hexagonal number can be written
as

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_n &= n(2n-1) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, every hexagonal number
$h_n$ is divisible by $n$, so we can easily produce another
hexagonal number divisible by $9$, for example

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_9 &= 2\left(9^2\right)-9 \\[12pt]
  &= 2(81)-9 \\[12pt]
  &= 153 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Therefore, the statement is false.}}$
- Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_n &= 2n^2 - n, \hspace{3em} [\hspace{0.1em}\text{for $n \in \mathbb{N}$}\hspace{0.1em}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n \in \mathbb{N}$.
  Base case. For $n = 1$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_1 &= 1 \\[12pt]
  &= 2(1)^2 - 1 \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence P$(1)$ holds.
  Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for
some $k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_k &= 2k^2-k \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  for some $k \geq 1$.
  Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need
to show that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_{k+1} &= 2(k+1)^2 - (k+1) \hspace{2.2em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_{k+1} &= h_k + (4k + 1) \\[12pt]
  &= 2k^2 - k + (4k + 1) \hspace{3em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[12pt]
  &= 2k^2 + 3k + 1 \\[12pt]
  &= 2\left(k^2 + 2k + 1\right) - (k+1) \\[12pt]
  &= 2(k+1)^2 - (k+1) \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
  Conclusion.
  P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
  $\answer{\text{Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$.}}$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
- Use de Moivre's theorem to find the value of
$\left[\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right)\right]^{12}$.
[2]

- Use mathematical induction to prove that

  $$
  \hspace{3.5em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n = \cos (n\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha) \hspace{1em} \text{for all } n \in \mathbb{Z}^+. 
  $$

  [6]


Let
$w = \cos \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha$.

- Find an expression in terms of $\alpha$ for
$w^n - (w^\ast)^n$, $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, where $w^\ast$ is
the complex conjugate of $w$. [2]

- 
  - Show that $ww^\ast = 1$.
  - Write down and simplify the binomial expansion of
$(w - w^\ast)^3$ in terms of $w$ and $w^\ast$.
  - Hence show that
$\sin (3\alpha) = 3\sin \alpha - 4 \sin^3 \alpha$. [5]


- Hence solve
$4\sin^3\alpha + (2 \cos \alpha - 3) \sin \alpha = 0$ for
$0 \leq \alpha \leq \pi$. [6]
list.markScheme:
- Using de Moivre's theorem, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \left[\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right)\right]^{12} &= \cos\Big(\dfrac{12\pi}{6}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \Big(\dfrac{12\pi}{6}\Big) \\[6pt]
  &= \cos 2\pi + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin 2\pi \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= 1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.6em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n = \cos (n\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha) \hspace{2.5em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

Base case. For $n = 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.3em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^1 &= \cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \\[3pt]
&= \cos (1\cdot\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (1\cdot\alpha)\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^k = \cos (k\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha) \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{4em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^{k+1} = \cos ((k+1)\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin ((k+1)\alpha) \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.5em} &(\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^{k+1} = \\[5pt]
&= (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^k\cos \alpha - (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^k ({\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha) \\[6pt]
&= [\cos (k\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha)]\cos \alpha - [\cos (k\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha)] ({\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)  \hspace{2em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[6pt]
&= \cos (k\alpha)\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha) \cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\cos (k\alpha) \sin \alpha - \sin (k\alpha)\sin \alpha \\[6pt]
&= [\cos (k\alpha)\cos \alpha - \sin (k\alpha)\sin \alpha] - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}[\sin (k\alpha) \cos \alpha + \cos (k\alpha) \sin \alpha]  \\[6pt]
&= \cos((k+1)\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin((k+1)\alpha) \hspace{2em} [\text{by compound angle formulas}]\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

- Using de Moivre's theorem and the identity $(2)$ from part
(b), we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  w^n - (w^\ast)^n &= (\cos \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n - (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n \\[6pt]
  &= [\hspace{0.05em}\cos (n\alpha) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha)] - [\hspace{0.05em}\cos (n\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha)] \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha)} \qref{(3)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The product of $w$ and its conjugate is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.2em} ww^\ast &= (\cos \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)(\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha) \\[6pt]
    &= \cos^2 \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\cos \alpha \sin \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \cos \alpha + \sin^2 \alpha \\[6pt]
    &= \cos^2 \alpha + \sin^2 \alpha \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 1}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we simplify the binomial expansion of $(w - w^\ast)^3$, we
get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    (w - w^\ast)^3 &= w^3 - 3w^2w^\ast + 3w(w^\ast)^2 - (w^\ast)^3 \\[6pt]
    &= w^3 - 3w(ww^\ast) + 3w^\ast(ww^\ast) - (w^\ast)^3 \\[6pt]
    &= w^3 - 3w + 3w^\ast - (w^\ast)^3 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (d) (i)}] \hspace{0.7em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= w^3 - (w^\ast)^3 - 3(w - w^\ast)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Substituting $n = 1$ and $n = 3$ in the identity $(3)$ from part
(c), we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    n=1 &: \hspace{0.5em} w - (w^\ast) = 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \\[6pt]
    n=3 &: \hspace{0.5em} w^3 - (w^\ast)^3 = 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (3\alpha)\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, from part d (ii), we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.3em} (w - w^\ast)^3 &= w^3 - (w^\ast)^3 - 3\hspace{0.05em}(w - w^\ast) \\[6pt]
    (2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^3 &= 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (3\alpha) - 3\hspace{0.05em}(2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha) \\[6pt]
    -8{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin^3 \alpha &= 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (3\alpha) - 6{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \\[6pt]
    4\sin^3 \alpha &= -\sin (3\alpha) + 3 \sin \alpha \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{\sin (3\alpha) = 3 \sin \alpha -4\sin^3 \alpha} \hspace{0.9em}
    $$


- If we rewrite the given equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  4\sin^3\alpha + (2 \cos \alpha - 3) \sin \alpha &= 0 \\[6pt]
  2\sin \alpha \cos \alpha  &= 3\sin \alpha - 4\sin^3\alpha \\[7pt]
  \sin (2\alpha) &= \sin (3\alpha) \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (d) (iii)}] \hspace{1em} \qref{(4)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(4)$ for $\alpha$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.7em} \alpha &= 0 \hspace{0.75em}\text{or}\hspace{0.75em} 3\alpha = k\pi - 2\alpha \hspace{2.2em} [\text{where $k$ is an odd integer}] \\[7pt]
  \hspace{8.7em} \alpha &= 0 \hspace{0.75em}\text{or}\hspace{0.75em} \alpha = \dfrac{k\pi}{5} \hspace{2em} [\text{where $k = 1,3,5$ since $\alpha \in [0,\pi]$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{\alpha = 0,\hspace{0.25em} \dfrac{\pi}{5},\hspace{0.25em} \dfrac{3\pi}{5},\hspace{0.25em} \pi} \hspace{8.55em}
  $$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Let $f(x) = (x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}}$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Find $f'(x)$.  [2]

- Prove by induction that
$\dfrac{\mathrm{d}^nf}{\mathrm{d}x^n} = \bigg(\dfrac{3n + x - 1}{3^n}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}}$
for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.  [7]

- Find the coordinates of any local maximum and minimum points on the
graph of $y = f(x)$. Justify whether such point is a maximum or a
minimum. [5]

- Find the coordinates of any points of inflexion on the graph of
$y = f(x)$. Justify whether such point is a point of inflexion.
[5]

- Hence sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, indicating clearly the points
found in parts (c) and (d) and any intercepts with the axes.
[4]
list.markScheme:
- Using the product rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big[(x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}}\big] \\[6pt]
  &= e^{\frac{x}{3}} + \dfrac{1}{3}(x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \bigg(\dfrac{x+2}{3}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.7em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^nf}{\mathrm{d}x^n} = \bigg(\dfrac{3n + x - 1}{3^n}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

Base case. For $n = 1$, from part (a), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}x} = \bigg(\dfrac{3 + x - 1}{3}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} \end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.1em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^kf}{\mathrm{d}x^k} = \bigg(\dfrac{3k + x - 1}{3^k}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.2em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}f}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}} = \bigg[\dfrac{3(k+1) + x - 1}{3^{k+1}}\bigg]e^{\frac{x}{3}}\end{aligned}
$$

If we differentiate both sides of the equation (IH), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{4.9em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}f}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}} &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\bigg[\bigg(\dfrac{3k + x - 1}{3^k}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}}\bigg] \\[6pt]
&= \bigg(\dfrac{1}{3^k}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} + \dfrac{1}{3}\bigg(\dfrac{3k + x - 1}{3^k}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} \\[6pt]
&= \bigg[\dfrac{1}{3^k} + \dfrac{3k + x - 1}{3^{k+1}}\bigg]e^{\frac{x}{3}} \\[6pt]
&= \bigg[\dfrac{3(k+1) + x - 1}{3^{k+1}}\bigg]e^{\frac{x}{3}}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

- If we solve the equation $f'(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \bigg(\dfrac{x + 2}{3}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} &= 0 \\[6pt]
  x + 2 &= 0 \\[12pt] 
  x &= -2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $-2$ is the only critical number of
$f$.
  Using the ID Test, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3446dd1a-9a13-43e5-8af3-ee3cf0e76f4c/images/6df8b040-2aba-4405-8103-6cc64148c86f/41f59f91431e030c029eab143139497c30f1df01.svg)


  The sign of $f'$ changes from negative to positive at $-2$.
  Hence, by the First Derivative Test, $f$ has a local minimum at
$-2$.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = -2$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= f(-2) \\[6pt]
  &= (-2-1)e^{-\frac{2}{3}} \\[6pt]
  &= -3e^{-\frac{2}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the graph of $y = f(x)$
has a local minimum at
$\answer{\mathrm{A}\big(\hspace{-0.2em}-2,-3e^{-\frac{2}{3}}\big)}$.
- If we solve the equation $f''(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \bigg[\dfrac{3(2) + x - 1}{3^2}\bigg]e^{\frac{x}{3}} &= 0 \\[6pt]  
  3(2) + x - 1 &= 0 \\[12pt] 
  x &= -5\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence there is at most one point of inflexion
on the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  Using the Concavity Test, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3446dd1a-9a13-43e5-8af3-ee3cf0e76f4c/images/44ae7137-2675-4b13-8b95-c1dd8eee70fc/1c4ca00263d0aa013c934479ae539a797857f949.svg)


  The graph of $y = f(x)$ changes concavity from downward to upward at
$-5$.
  Hence the graph of $y = f(x)$ has an inflexion point at $-5$.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = -5$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= f(-5) \\[6pt]
  &= (-5-1)e^{-\frac{5}{3}} \\[6pt]
  &= -6e^{-\frac{5}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the graph of $y = f(x)$
has the inflexion point at
$\answer{\mathrm{B}\big(\hspace{-0.2em}-5,-6e^{-\frac{5}{3}}\big)}$.
- We first note that the domain of the function
$f(x) = (x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}}$ is $(-\infty,\infty)$.
  Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}} &= 0 \\[6pt]
  x-1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  x &= 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point
$\answer{\mathrm{C}(1,0)}$
is the $x$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
  &= (0-1)e^{0} \\[6pt]
  &= -1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point
$\answer{\mathrm{D}(0,-1)}$
is the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x\rightarrow -\infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x\rightarrow -\infty} \big[(x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}}\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x\rightarrow \infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x\rightarrow \infty} \big[(x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}}\big] \\[6pt]
  &= \infty\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the $x$-axis is a horizontal
asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ indicating the points A, B, C &
D, we have

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
Let $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-x}}$,$x < 1$.

- Show that $f''(x) = \dfrac{3}{4} (1-x)^{\frac{-5}{2}}$. [3]

- Use mathematical induction to prove that[9]


  $$
  f^{(n)}(x) = \left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)^n \dfrac{(2n)!}{n!} (1-x)^{\frac{-1}{2}-n} \quad n\in \mathbb{Z},\enskip n\geq 2.
  $$


Let $g(x)=\cos (mx)$, $m\in \mathbb{Q}$.
Consider the function $h$ defined by $h(x)=f(x) \times g(x)$ for $x<1$.
The $x^2$ term in the Maclaurin series for $h(x)$ has a coefficient of
$-\dfrac{3}{4}$.

- Find the possible values of $m$.  [9]
list.markScheme:
- Taking the derivative with respect to $x$ twice, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f'(x) 
  %&= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-x}} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \left(1-x\right)^{\frac{-1}{2}} \\[10pt]
  &=  \dfrac{1}{2} (1-x)^{\frac{-3}{2}} \\[10pt]
  f''(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \left[\dfrac{1}{2} (1-x)^{\frac{-3}{2}}\right] \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{3}{4} (1-x)^{\frac{-5}{2}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $\mathrm{P}(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^nf}{\mathrm{d}x^n} = \left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)^n \dfrac{(2n)!}{n!} (1-x)^{\frac{-1}{2}-n} \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}$,} \enskip n\geq 2]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that $\mathrm{P}(n)$
holds for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}$, $n\geq2$.
  Base case. For $n = 2$, from part (a), we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^2f}{\mathrm{d}x^2} = \dfrac{3}{4} (1-x)^{\frac{-5}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence P$(2)$ holds.
  Inductive hypothesis. We assume that $\mathrm{P}(k)$
holds for some $k \geq 2$. In other words, we assume that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^kf}{\mathrm{d}x^k} = \left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)^k \dfrac{(2k)!}{k!} (1-x)^{\frac{-1}{2}-k} \hspace{0.5em} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  for some $k \geq 2$.
  Inductive step. To show that $\mathrm{P}(k+1)$ holds,
we need to show that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}f}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}} = \left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)^{k+1} \dfrac{(2k+2)!}{(k+1)!} (1-x)^{\frac{-1}{2}-k-1}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we differentiate both sides of the equation (IH), we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.55em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}f}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}} &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left[\left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)^k \dfrac{(2k)!}{k!} (1-x)^{\frac{-1}{2}-k}\right] \\[14pt]
  &= \left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)^k \dfrac{(2k)!}{k!} \left(k+\dfrac{1}{2}\right)(1-x)^{\frac{-1}{2}-k-1} \\[16pt]
  &= \left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)^{k+1} \dfrac{(2k)!}{k!} \left(4k+2\right)(1-x)^{\frac{-1}{2}-k-1} \\[16pt]
  &= \left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)^{k+1} \dfrac{(2k)!}{k!} \left(\dfrac{(2k+2)(2k+1)}{k+1}\right)(1-x)^{\frac{-1}{2}-k-1} \\[16pt]
  &= \left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)^{k+1} \dfrac{(2k+2)!}{(k+1)!}(1-x)^{\frac{-1}{2}-k-1}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $P(k+1)$ holds as well.
  Conclusion. P$(2)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 2$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
  Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n \in \mathbb{Z}$, $n\geq2$.
- First, we obtain the second derivative of $h$, using the product
rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \big[f(x)\times g(x)\big] \\[12pt]
  &= f'(x)g(x)+f(x)g'(x) \\[10pt]
  h''(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \big[f'(x)g(x)+f(x)g'(x)\big] \\[12pt]
  &= f''(x)g(x)+2f'(x)g'(x)+f(x)g''(x) \\[13pt]
  h''(0) &= f''(0)g(0)+2f'(0)g'(0)+f(0)g''(0) \qref{(1)} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  From part (a), we have the following evaluations at $x=0$

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-x}} & f(0) &= 1 \\[10pt]
  f'(x) &= \dfrac{1}{2}(1-x)^{-3/2} & f'(0) &=\dfrac{1}{2} \\[10pt]
  f''(x) &= \dfrac{3}{4} (1-x)^{-5/2} & f''(0) &= \dfrac{3}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and the respective evaluations for $g(x)$ and its derivatives are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g(x) &= \cos(mx) & g(0) &= 1 \\[12pt]
  g'(x) &= -m\sin(mx) & g'(0) &=0 \\[12pt]
  g''(x) &= -m^2\cos(mx) & g''(0) &= -m^2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, substituting the respective values into equation (1), we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h''(0) &= \left(\dfrac{3}{4}\right)(1) + 2\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)(0)+(1)(-m^2)\\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{3}{4}-m^2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Finally, using the formula
for the $x^2$ term in the Maclaurin series of $h(x)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{h''(0)}{2} &= -\dfrac{3}{4} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{3}{4}-m^2 &= -\dfrac{6}{4} \\[12pt]
  m^2 &= \dfrac{9}{4} \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-3mm}\answer{m = \pm \dfrac{3}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.content:
The following diagram shows the graph of
$y=\arctan(2x-3)+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$ for $x\in \mathbb{R}$,
with asymptotes at $y=\dfrac{\pi}{4}$ and $y=\dfrac{5\pi}{4}$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/94f32658-f1f8-4e8a-a7ec-64540cbb0149/images/f7349dc1-1bf4-4e25-a560-7f6b11100f20/081334c23d135e25efc729fff5cf10e0f4fe7363.svg)



- Describe a sequence of transformations that transforms the graph of
$y=\arctan x$ to the graph of $y=\arctan(2x-3)+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$ for
$x\in \mathbb{R}$.[3]

- Show that
$\arctan p - \arctan q \equiv \arctan \left(\dfrac{p-q}{1+pq}\right)$.[3]

- Verify that
$\arctan(x+2)-\arctan(x+1) = \arctan\left( \dfrac{1}{(x+1)^2+(x+1)+1}\right)$.[3]

- Using mathematical induction and the results from part (b) and
(c), prove that[8]


  $$
  \sum_{r=1}^n \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) = \arctan(n+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} \hspace{0.8em} \text{for } n\in \mathbb{Z}^{+}.
  $$
list.markScheme:
- The function can be expressed as
$y=\arctan\left(2\left(x-\dfrac{3}{2}\right)\right)+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$,
hence we get the following transformations in order

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{transformation $1$}&: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{horizontal stretch by a factor of $\dfrac{1}{2}$}} \\[10pt]
  \text{transformation $2$}&:
  \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{horizontal translation $\dfrac{3}{2}$ units right}}\\[10pt]
  \text{transformation $3$}&: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{vertical translation $\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$ units up}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Note that the vertical shift, which is transformation $3$, can also be performed before the horizontal transformations.
- Using the compound angle identity, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \tan\left(\arctan p - \arctan q \right) &= \dfrac{\tan(\arctan p)-\tan(\arctan q)}{1+\tan(\arctan p)\tan(\arctan q)} \\[12pt]
  &=\dfrac{p-q}{1+pq} \\[12pt]\\
  \intertext{Finally, taking the $\arctan$ on both sides}\\
  &\hspace{-2.85cm}\answer{\arctan p - \arctan q \equiv \arctan \left(\dfrac{p-q}{1+pq}\right)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the formula from part (b), we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arctan(x+2)-\arctan(x+1) &= \arctan\left(\dfrac{(x+2)-(x+1)}{1+(x+2)(x+1)}\right)\\[12pt]
  &= \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{((x+1)+1)(x+1)+1}\right)\\[12pt]
  &\hspace{0.2em}\answer{=\arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{(x+1)^2+(x+1)+1}\right)} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $\mathrm{P}(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^n \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) &= \arctan(n+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} \hspace{3em} \big[\,\text{for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$}\,\big]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that $\mathrm{P}(n)$
holds for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$.
  Base case. For $n = 1$, from part (a), we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{(1)^2+1+1}\right) &= \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right) \\[10pt]
  &= \arctan(2)-\arctan(1) \hspace{3em} \big[\text{by part (b,c)}\big]\\[12pt]
  &= \arctan(2)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence P$(1)$ holds.
  Inductive hypothesis. We assume that $\mathrm{P}(k)$
holds for some $k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^k \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) = \arctan(k+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} \hspace{0.5em} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  for some $k \geq 1$.
  Inductive step. To show that $\mathrm{P}(k+1)$ holds,
we need to show that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^{k+1} \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) = \arctan(k+2)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we add the $k+1$ term to both sides of the equation (IH), we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^{k+1} \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) &= \arctan(k+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} + \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{(k+1)^2+(k+1)+1}\right)\\[10pt]
  \big[\text{by part (c)}\big]\hspace{3em} &= \arctan(k+2) - \arctan(k+1) + \arctan(k+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\\[12pt]
  &= \arctan(k+2)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $P(k+1)$ holds
as well.
  Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
  Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$.
